title: Episode 159 – Helen Atthowe, Author, “The Ecological Farm”
subtitle: About Simple Gardening Wisdom Video Course
description: Helen Atthowe is one of the featured VIP speakers in the Y on Earth Community’s new “Simple Gardening Wisdom Video Course” (SGWVC) which is currently being offered at a special “Launch Package” discount rate – sign up today to secure your specially discounted spot in the course, and enjoy a full module with Helen Atthowe along with several other special experts and Chelsea Green Publishing authors.

about_sections.about_simple_gardening_wisdom_video_cour: Helen Atthowe is one of the featured VIP speakers in the Y on Earth Community’s new “Simple Gardening Wisdom Video Course” (SGWVC) which is currently being offered at a special “Launch Package” discount rate – sign up today to secure your specially discounted spot in the course, and enjoy a full module with Helen Atthowe along with several other special experts and Chelsea Green Publishing authors.
about_sections.about_chelsea_green_publishing: Founded in 1984, Chelsea Green Publishing is recognized as a leading publisher of books on the politics and practice of sustainable living, publishing authors who bring in-depth, practical knowledge to life, and give readers hands-on information related to organic farming and gardening, permaculture, ecology, the environment, simple living, food, sustainable business and economics, green building, and more. VisitChelsea Green’s special Y on Earth Community Podcastpage to see other episodes with CGP authors. (And, get a 35% discount on all Chelsea Green books and audiobooks using the code:YOE35)
about_sections.about_helen_atthowe: Helen Atthowe has worked for 35 years to connect farming, food systems, land stewardship, and conservation. She bought a new farm in Montana in 2023, but still consults for and monitors on-going research at Woodleaf Farm in eastern Oregon. She serves as a consultant with farmers across the United States and internationally. Helen and her late husband, Carl Rosato, co-owned and operated a certified organic orchard in California where they pioneered methods for raising apples, peaches, and other tree fruits without the use of any type of pesticides. Her on-farm research includes ecological weed and insect management, organic minimal soil disturbance systems for vegetable and orchard crops, and managing living mulches for soil and habitat building. She is a contributing write toThe Organic Gardener’s Handbook of Natural Pest and Disease Controland other books. She has served as a board member for the Organic Farming Research Foundation and adviser for the Wild Farm Alliance. Helen has a master’s degree in horticulture from Rutgers University and has worked in education and research at the University of Arkansas, Rutgers University, and Oregon State University, and served as a horticulture extension agent in Montana, where she annually taught an organic Master Gardener Course.

full_transcript:
[11.1s - 25.0s]: Welcome to the Y on Earth Community Podcast. I'm your host, Aaron William Perry. And today we're visiting with the author of the ecological farm, Helen Atto, Hi Helen. How are you today?

[25.0s - 37.5s]: I'm great. Thank you. I'm so happy. We have the opportunity to talk with you about your incredible book. It's beautiful and such a robust resource.

[38.9s - 43.5s]: Thank you. It's an honor to be here. I appreciate your kind words.

[45.0s - 62.0s]: Helen Atto has worked for 35 years to connect farming food systems, land stewardship and conservation. She bought a new farm in Montana in 2023, but still consults for and monitors ongoing research at Woodley Farm in Eastern Oregon.

[63.0s - 84.0s]: She serves as a consultant with farmers across the United States and internationally. Helen and her late husband, Carl Rosado, co-owned and operated a certified organic orchard in California, where they pioneered methods for raising apples, peaches and other tree fruits without the use of any type of pesticides.

[85.0s - 101.4s]: Her on farm research includes ecological weed and insect management, organic minimal soil disturbance systems for vegetable and orchard crops and managing living mulches for soil and habitat building.

[102.4s - 118.7s]: She is a contributing writer to the organic gardeners' handbook of natural pest and disease controlling other books. She has served as a board member for the Organic Farming Research Foundation and Advisor for the Wild Farm Alliance.

[118.7s - 138.2s]: She has a master's degree in horticulture from Rutgers University and has worked in education and research at the University of Arkansas, Rutgers University and Oregon State University and served as a horticulture extension agent in Montana, where she annually taught and organic master gardener course.

[138.2s - 150.6s]: Now, Helen, this book, of course, is published by our good friends at Chelsea Green Publishing and I'm holding this up for the camera here for our video audience.

[150.6s - 176.7s]: It is such an incredible resource, truly an amazing comprehensive and detailed resource and it is also absolutely beautiful. It has so many wonderful photos and a variety of other charting graphics to help us understand some of these complex issues and yeah, congrats this book is so beautiful.

[178.6s - 195.4s]: Thank you. Chelsea Green, very patient with me with all the photographs that I've taken from all three farms that I have owned and operated in Montana and California and Oregon and now back to Montana again.

[196.6s - 198.0s]: Full circle, right?

[199.3s - 200.6s]: Full circle indeed.

[202.0s - 229.6s]: Well, I'd like to kind of dive right in because basically the book you've got it organized in two major sections and at the beginning of the first section, you describe the principles for managing ecological relationships, which really helps to frame up, I think, best practices and in the right sort of philosophical practical.

[229.6s - 236.4s]: So, I think that's a very practical approach to taking good care of our gardens and our farms, our soil and our plants.

[237.1s - 246.9s]: I was hoping to kick us off. You could walk us through the principles, which I've gotten written out here if you want me to enumerate them and you probably have the memorized.

[248.0s - 274.6s]: I do, I don't have the memorized in order anymore, I kind of have the memorized in the ones that that I find to be the most vital and I do need to tell you that my late husband, Carl and I worked on all of those principles and again came up with them as we did experiments and and managed our farms in California and Montana and then in Oregon.

[274.6s - 298.1s]: But we did borrow the first three are borrowed from the USDA soil health initiative, which is kind of interesting because it shows that so many of us are thinking about what is vital for soil and farm and garden health, I think now.

[298.1s - 326.9s]: So, I think what I might do is touch on the most important of them and how they interact because what Carl and I realized as we continued farming that we started out, you know, all about yield and trying to get good organic yields and trying to figure out what to do to grow our particular crops as well as we could organically.

[326.9s - 349.9s]: And over time we evolved to this realization that it was less about focusing on individual crops and more about all of the ecological function within the farm environment and and all of the interacting and overlapping ecological principles.

[349.9s - 377.8s]: So, when I talk about these 10 principles, they all interact. So, the first three or four focus on soil and most vitally as I'm sure your audience is well aware of where we're preaching to the choir here when we say that above ground and below ground diversity is the key to managing ecological principles.

[377.8s - 400.8s]: And we want to have as much plant diversity both above ground and below ground as possible to encourage a healthy and strong microbial community in that magic area, the rises fear, which is where the soil and the microbes and the plant roots are commingled together.

[400.8s - 420.8s]: And if there's one magic place in our garden, it's the rises fear. So, diversity, then the next one is once we have this lovely diversity or as we're building up plant diversity and microbial diversity, we want to disturb it as little as possible.

[420.8s - 434.0s]: And one of the ways to think about that is how can we disturb the soil as little as possible so that we can maintain a living root year round.

[434.1s - 444.2s]: That doesn't necessarily mean a growing root in Montana, when the ground is freezing, we don't necessarily have growing roots but we have living roots.

[444.2s - 459.8s]: And then we move on to get a little more specific and say try and focus on a carbon-based system rather than a high nitrogen-based system.

[459.8s - 472.7s]: We used to as farmers and gardeners say, well, let's just figure out how to get as much nitrogen and phosphorus and potassium, all the nutrients but particularly nitrogen to the crops as possible.

[472.7s - 496.5s]: But over time, we learned and now the soil, microbial and biochemical research is starting to agree and concur or we're concurring with them that a higher carbon-based system, meaning that there's more carbon than nitrogen.

[496.5s - 509.6s]: So the ratio of carbon to nitrogen in the things that we add to our soils, the fertilizers, the soil amendments, the carbon part is higher than the nitrogen part.

[510.7s - 524.3s]: And then as we focus on a carbon-based rather than a super-over-nitrogen fertilizer system or soil fertility system, we want to think about where that carbon comes from.

[524.3s - 539.2s]: And can we grow our own carbon or collect our carbon as close to our gardens and farms as possible rather than importing it from somewhere else?

[539.2s - 569.2s]: And then we move on to how the things below ground and the soil health of the system interacts with things like, well, some people call them weeds, we'll call them other vegetation, non-crop vegetation, and insects in the system and other microorganisms, the good guys and the ones we aren't as happy with.

[569.2s - 590.0s]: The ones that cause disease. So what we try to do with building the soil system is have it also multi-tack as building a habitat system, a habitat for beneficial soil microorganisms and beneficial insects,

[590.0s - 608.2s]: soil our predators and parasites that prey upon pest insects, and then also beneficial microorganisms and insects that prey upon disease pathogens and even weed seeds.

[608.2s - 636.3s]: So we're trying to create habitat as we create soil. So we're choosing a soil fertility system that also maintains a living root in the soil and maintains season-long sequential bloom for especially predators and parasites that require pollen and nectar as their food.

[636.3s - 656.1s]: And then we're trying to fertilize only selectively, weed only selectively, and maintain undisturbed habitat in a good portion of the farm or the garden at any one time.

[656.1s - 677.0s]: And that kind of brings all of the 10 principles together into the overlapping ecological system, but you can just read through the principles one at a time, always remembering that you really can't take one without the other or others.

[677.6s - 680.7s]: Oh, wonderful. So I think you're too nerdy on that.

[681.5s - 698.6s]: That's perfect. I love it. And yeah, if you if you're okay with it, I think I'll go ahead and read the 10 in order as you lay them out in the book because I think it really helps a lot of us kind of get oriented in this kind of complex system.

[698.6s - 722.3s]: So yeah, number one is you're going to laugh and I'm in a laugh and say that my husband and I never believed in recipes, but we came up with these 10 principles because people always wanted recipes. So absolutely, I've given given the nerdy big picture of how all the principles interact. Now you give it to us as a recipe.

[722.3s - 744.6s]: Yeah, here's the recipe and on that note, I've been able to myself learn some techniques for cooking from some remarkable chefs over the years. And so I rarely use recipes. And of course, for many of us who want to do more gardening and have more success gardening and farming, the recipes can be helpful.

[744.6s - 759.5s]: And to that end, I'm thrilled to share and announce that in partnership with Chelsea Green Publishing and others, the wider community is rolling out our simple gardening wisdom video course.

[759.5s - 779.6s]: And of course, there's a module that you've provided, Helen, that is so informative and helpful just helping us all get a bit more comfortable so that perhaps one day many more of us won't need the recipes any longer.

[782.0s - 787.2s]: Absolutely, and I still use them too, but I'm I'm I'm teasing.

[787.2s - 809.2s]: Yeah, so here's here's how you lay it laid out in the book. It's it's number one. Create above and below ground diversity. Number two, minimize soil disturbances. Number three, maintain growing roots. You're round. Number four, grow your own carbon. Number five, add organic residues. All season.

[809.2s - 825.5s]: Number six, focus on carbon fertilizers. Number seven, recycle rather than important nutrients. Number eight, fertilize selectively. Number nine, weed selectively. And number 10, create habitat in the field essentially kind of reintering what you've already just articulated.

[825.5s - 845.5s]: But I gotta say like one of the things I really appreciate about your book is that it is absolutely chalk full of very specific methods and strategies to manage all kinds of situations and scenarios that will encounter in our gardens and in our farms and orchards.

[845.7s - 865.5s]: And the way you've organized the book is makes it so useful and not nearly I think as intimidating as it as it might otherwise be. And I noted a few specifics that I wanted to share their audience and discuss with you, but before getting to that.

[865.5s - 885.2s]: I wanted to ask just out of curiosity being an author myself, you mentioned that Chelsea Green was patient with you. How long did it take you to put this book together because it clearly has many years worth of experience and wisdom in it.

[886.5s - 907.0s]: Actually, it's really about 40 years. So I started doing on farm research in the 1990s on my farm in Montana and in the early 2000s and I got research grants and so I would of course write it all down and do even more monitoring.

[907.0s - 936.9s]: So I had all of that detail and then my brewing in husband was doing his own on farm research in California and ironically we were developing similar methods using living mulchus for example to to maintain our living root in the soil year round as well as our crops and to create habitat for the soil.

[937.0s - 960.4s]: So that is close to our crops as possible. So we used living mulches and and then when we met we had the courage to push ourselves even further on his farm in California where he was of course, remember doing perennial crops orchard crops and in Montana, I was mainly doing annual crops mainly vegetables.

[960.4s - 974.7s]: So we did on farm research together and of course we kept all of our notes and that went into the book and then we moved to Oregon and started a farm together and we went crazy.

[974.7s - 1002.7s]: We really pushed the ecological envelope as far as we could go and we set up some long term experiments to see what could we really get away with in terms of those 10 ecological principles, how far could we really go to not disturbing the soil, how much no till could we do with the orchard it was easy and we kept good records of that.

[1002.7s - 1021.1s]: A little more challenging with the annual vegetable crops and we kept records of that. So between Carl's farm and my farm in Montana and then getting together and farming together in California and then in Oregon, it was 40 years.

[1021.1s - 1050.5s]: It took about a year to write the book and do literature searches because I wanted to see what what the science was saying about some of these things Carl and I were excited about and then Chelsea Green, my wonderful editor at Chelsea Green helped me and was very firm with making it less ecologically complex.

[1051.5s - 1078.9s]: So we maintained the ecological complexity but we wrote about it in a way that wasn't quite so complex. So thank you for that. The first section is is is pretty unusual and then the second section we get into well, okay, we want to talk about managing ecological principles and and we want to talk about how to do.

[1078.9s - 1098.2s]: How to practically do all of those things that are in the 10 ecological principles but okay, so if you're starting with a low soil fertility system or if you're starting with a garden or a farm that has particular pest or disease problems, then what do you do?

[1098.2s - 1118.4s]: And the second half of the book is basically all of that but still making sure that we remember that there are ecological impacts to everything we do. So so I present the least ecological impact up to the heavier ecological impact in the second part.

[1118.7s - 1120.8s]: And that's why it took long to write the book.

[1121.7s - 1150.8s]: Yeah, it will it's it's really such a tremendous resource and I'm excited to dive into a few of the details with you and yet we'll nerd out a little bit but I thought with your permission, I would quote you reading the final paragraph of your introduction because it sets such a sweet and I might even say,

[1150.8s - 1165.6s]: a spiritual tone to the experience you're sharing with us working with these ecosystems, these organisms, the soil and so forth. And may I read this quoting you?

[1165.7s - 1166.1s]: Absolutely.

[1167.1s - 1188.5s]: Okay, you write when you are feeling troubled, fearful or uncertain, there is a certainty intending plants and growing your own food, nurturing the healthy goodness in a field of multi colored kale and lettuces or coapsing so much sweetness from a special peach tree.

[1188.5s - 1193.8s]: It all makes me feel I belong safely wherever I am.

[1194.7s - 1208.0s]: The process of creating farms and gardens opens my eyes to awe, tunes my ears to listening and offers the gifts of curiosity, discovery and deep connection.

[1209.0s - 1228.1s]: Being part of this farming revolution, I reap my own personal revolution for free, healthy farming in which nature is invited to participate, grows healthy food that in turn grows healthy humans resistant to disease and stress.

[1228.1s - 1238.6s]: These reconnected healthy farms and gardens are in turn resilient and resistant to plant disease and stress.

[1239.9s - 1257.2s]: And it's just such a, when I've read that, I was stunned. I loved the way in which you speak to the deep solace in sanctuary, so many of us experience when we're gardening and farming.

[1257.2s - 1268.1s]: And kind of leave us with that in the introduction as we start our journey into a whole lot of very, very practical and technical information.

[1269.3s - 1287.1s]: Isn't it lovely the synergy between human health, farm health, soil health, environmental health and that when we stop and pay attention, I think we can, we can feel and see that synergy.

[1288.3s - 1301.3s]: No doubt about it and perhaps among the many great tasks before us, before humanity, this particular work is core and central.

[1303.0s - 1309.6s]: Yes, good food growing makes good humans. I think you hit the nail on the head.

[1310.6s - 1339.3s]: I absolutely love it. Well, let's let's nerd out just a little bit. I was struck. I mean, throughout this book, not only are there many beautiful photographs, there are also many very compelling charts, flow charts, data charts to help us pretty quickly understand the information that you're conveying and the strategies and methods that you're sharing.

[1339.3s - 1353.0s]: One that jumped out at me is on page 33, the soil revolution section and it's the complex, relatively complex interconnectedness.

[1353.4s - 1367.6s]: We see going on with the roots, the rhizosphere with nutrients, microbial activity, organic carbon, luteolin, rhizobia, bacteria, biochannin, I don't even know if I'm saying that right.

[1367.6s - 1373.2s]: Are muscular micro-rise, can you walk us through what's going on in this picture?

[1374.2s - 1380.3s]: And you know, you're going to laugh at me, but actually, I simplified that.

[1381.3s - 1394.1s]: So there are still that's the rhizosphere that I was talking about in a very beginning. That's the magic if we have a magic area in in farming and gardening.

[1394.3s - 1406.5s]: It's right there in the rhizosphere because what's happening is the plant above ground is taking in carbon. It's taking it in sunlight.

[1406.5s - 1424.3s]: And then it's manufacturing compounds, biochemicals, proteins. And the carbon that it harvest from the sun ends up throughout the plant and a good portion in the roots.

[1424.3s - 1439.7s]: And then it leaks some of that carbon out or you could say it shares some of that carbon with the microbial community that is associating with the roots.

[1439.7s - 1461.7s]: And then a myriad of things are going on. There are different, not only just carbon is being leaked out of the root, but some of those biochemicals that the plant makes are being leaked out or shared with the microbial community.

[1461.7s - 1471.4s]: And they act as signals and they signal different microorganisms to associate with the roots.

[1471.9s - 1489.1s]: And for example, one that probably everybody's heard about is mycorrhizae. And mycorrhizae, associate and become interconnected with the root because of a biochemical that that plant exudes.

[1489.1s - 1510.4s]: And the mycorrhizae, I know you and that starts the association. And then the association, that interaction with this particular fungi, the mycorrhizae, then allows other things to go back to the plant.

[1510.4s - 1520.8s]: And in this case with mycorrhizae, it's recycled phosphorus and nitrogen. And what mycorrhizae do, they're associated with the plant root.

[1521.2s - 1538.7s]: But they basically extend that plant's root out into the soil farther than the plant root could go on its own because that wonderful mycorrhizae has mycelium that just grows out into the soil.

[1538.7s - 1546.5s]: That's just one example. There are so many other microorganisms.

[1546.8s - 1559.8s]: You mentioned rhizobium, of course, are the bacteria that associate with a legume root and allow it to fix nitrogen from the atmosphere.

[1559.8s - 1576.2s]: And so then it doesn't need as much from the soil. But there's a whole bunch of other things going on. There are antibiotic microorganisms that are helping create a disease-free environment.

[1576.2s - 1589.4s]: There are microorganisms that help plants take up and utilize iron and a micronutrient. And of course, it's not all just good guys.

[1589.7s - 1597.7s]: There are microorganisms that can actually attack the plant and they too need a signal.

[1597.7s - 1620.8s]: So they need a biochemical coming from the plant and researchers are finding that plants, we're going to get back, of course, full circle to those plants that have a healthy amount of nutrients, but not an excess amount of nutrients like an excess amount of nitrogen, for example.

[1622.0s - 1636.5s]: Plants that are not healthy, exude different signals and then those disease-causing microorganisms say, oh, oh, I see that. That's my signal to move in.

[1636.5s - 1655.2s]: So what's happening is that half of what's going on is that the plant is communicating with the whole soil community with the biochemicals that it exudes.

[1655.2s - 1671.2s]: And then the other half is it's producing nutrients, what we call liquid carbon or some soil scientists called liquid carbon, that the microorganisms need for their growth and their health.

[1671.2s - 1689.8s]: And so there's a sharing going on on that side and then the microorganisms that are using that carbon might change things right at that root surface that makes it easier for other nutrients to be taken up by the root.

[1689.8s - 1706.3s]: So there's sharing and communicating and a complexity of biochemical interactions that allow nutrient cycling to be very efficient.

[1708.4s - 1735.5s]: I love it. I'm just smiling here to here right now. And you know, one of the things that has really impacted the work that we're doing at the White Earth community is not only literally working with the soil ecology, but also learning from it, metaphorically speaking, and thinking about a neural network.

[1735.5s - 1746.5s]: And analogy for the kind of work that we're doing through our ambassador network and in communities and with thought leaders and authors all around the world.

[1747.2s - 1760.9s]: And this this sense of connectivity, the sense of information sharing, this sense of resource sharing is so inspiring. And it's fundamental obviously to terrestrial life on this planet.

[1761.6s - 1772.4s]: And I forget where the quote comes from something like, you know, we all we humans owe our existence to a few inches of living soil and the fact that it rains or whatever.

[1772.4s - 1794.9s]: And I'm really curious, can you help our audience get the impression of how awesome these networks are, especially the high fee, mycelial networks, like how far they can reach and how many different plants and trees and various organisms can connect in with the network like that.

[1794.9s - 1813.9s]: You know, that's exactly that's so important what you said it shifts our paradigm doesn't it when we think in terms of these interconnections rather than discrete plants with discrete things happening like taking up fertilizer that we supply.

[1814.1s - 1843.9s]: It's a whole different perspective, I think so so yes, good for you. So my carize I do need to tell you the wonderful thing about my carize as that in native plant consist systems for a system, for example, they can be they are the norm rather than the anomaly and not just my carize but other fungi there's free living fungi.

[1843.9s - 1871.8s]: So by meaning that they're not associated with the roots there in just in the soil, there's free living bacteria as well as the plants associated fungi and bacteria, my carize are are make up the greatest biomass in the soil, but in native plant communities, they are the canary in the coal mine when it comes to disturbance and tillage.

[1871.8s - 1893.2s]: So if you till the soil too much if you disturb it with cultivation for managing weeds and if you over fertilize with higher nitrogen, higher phosphorus as opposed to higher arbon, which is what the microbial community really needs a lot of.

[1894.3s - 1923.1s]: You will create an environment where there may be no my carize which is very discouraging hence why we want to have those those living roots in the soil because remember my carize have to associate with the plant and then they're not free living and then they'll extend those those wonderful mycelian plants.

[1923.2s - 1937.0s]: So I'm going to put them in a very very far throughout a system where there are roots there for them to to go from one root to another root to another root.

[1937.0s - 1961.1s]: But if we disturb the soil, we won't have certainly the mycorrhizae the fungi in fact are the first ones to go when we garden or farm in a way that we add a lot of excessive fertilizer and that can even be too too much good fertilizer too much high nitrogen compost.

[1961.1s - 1976.9s]: We can there are other bacteria and other fungi that will dominate and the diversity of microorganisms will be diminished if that makes sense.

[1976.9s - 2006.9s]: Yes, quite yes and my understanding is that in native healthy ecosystems, we can see a micro isle high full networks extending across hundreds of square miles right presumably it's it's extraordinary if you have roots interconnecting or not even the roots interconnecting although that will happen in a good path.

[2006.9s - 2035.9s]: So in a poly culture or many species, the roots will actually share space but but in a forest where you have miles and miles of of of interactions, you have a whole diversity of micro organisms sharing root space and utilizing different resources so that they're not out competing each other for any one particular resource.

[2038.1s - 2047.9s]: Amazing yeah, may we may we humans learn from this wisdom and sophistication yeah yes.

[2049.0s - 2077.9s]: You know one of the resources that jumped out at me in the book in the minimizing tillage and growing your own fertilizer section is a layout of cover crops for different soil conditions and my goodness this helps us if you've got low fertility if you've got soil low soil organic matter if you're dealing with acidic or if on the other hand you're dealing with alkaline you provide here the many different cover crops.

[2077.9s - 2085.1s]: So we can get a crop species that we can select for those various scenarios I mean this is so so practical.

[2086.9s - 2106.9s]: And getting back up to the high full networks and and soil fungi one of the best ways to encourage micro is a is with cover crops and especially if you can minimize the tillage when you incorporate or you add

[2107.3s - 2137.2s]: that cover crop residue to your soil but a boy I was just reading an article looking at comparing high nitrogen fertilizer effects on the microbial community to lower nitrogen like like different cover crops and different plant residues and the data is very strong in which one will

[2137.2s - 2153.8s]: help encourage micro is a over systems that don't encourage micro is a and of course the best is is a forest garden where you always have a living route in the soil at at all times.

[2154.7s - 2183.1s]: Beautiful yeah in this reminds me of the practice of permaculture which of course your expert in and I got my permaculture design certification something like gosh almost 30 years ago and this whole notion of forest gardens in the in the stacked functions and the various levels of over story mid story under story and so on allows us to

[2183.1s - 2212.8s]: mimic the way natural forests are arranged basically right exactly I like to think of our our orchard systems or at least the orchards that that my late husband and I did and that I'm doing now on this new farm as as a forest garden with with mainly fruit producing tree biomass and then

[2212.8s - 2241.2s]: other other species to support the trees it's a little harder for me to do a commercial vegetable farm in in in that pattern but I'm learning the subtleties of different levels of of annuals and mixing areas that have perennials with air with areas that have

[2242.5s - 2270.9s]: just annual so I can I can have rows if I want them but then I have rows of perennials to beautiful absolutely beautiful let me remind our audience this is the why on earth community podcast I'm your host Aaron William Perry and today we're visiting with Helen at the author of the ecological farm a Chelsea green publishing book public

[2270.9s - 2296.4s]: book and I want to make sure to mention that folks can find many videos Helen that you've put together on YouTube at agrarian dreams and can also connect with you on a couple websites one is veganic permaculture dot com the other is wood leaf farm dot organ of course we'll provide the links in our show notes

[2351.7s - 2380.0s]: Chelsea green publishing Patagonia and elk run farm so check out the simple gardening wisdom video course to learn more of these tools techniques strategies ticks tricks and tips and there's a special module available with Helen exclusively so you can check all that out also a very special shout out and thank you to profitable purpose consulting

[2380.0s - 2408.6s]: working with B certified companies throughout the United States Europe and globally and shout out to wailing waters biodynamically grown hemp infused aroma therapy soaking salts for your well-being huge thanks to our network of ambassadors and our monthly supporters if you're not yet a monthly supporter or an ambassador and you'd like to join

[2408.6s - 2438.6s]: go to why on earth dot org get all that set up at whatever level you'd like join the ambassador network and you can also go over to our Patreon why on earth community podcast patreon is set things up there we've got many wonderful offerings and additional resources available to you there lastly one very special thing we do for our ambassadors in particular is provide a vast array of additional and

[2438.6s - 2467.6s]: ambassador resources including our behind the scenes segments with our podcast guests and so after we finish our main interview Helen and I will have a behind the scenes chat available to our ambassador network and so if you haven't yet joined and you'd like to you can go to why on earth dot org just click on the become an ambassador page and get your journey started with our beautiful growing network it's like a my sillial high f a network

[2467.7s - 2496.2s]: network worldwide of amazing people doing amazing work and yeah you know Helen I am just I'm so grateful that we've gotten connected and that you have organized so much information in this book in a way that is so useful and approachable and navigable and I want to ask a few other kind of nerdy questions because partly I'm curious and I imagine many of our audience will be as well

[2496.2s - 2520.6s]: can you explain for example what is it what is it cat time cat time on exchange capacity what does that mean yes cat on exchange capacity and that's one of the chemical components of the soil basically what I'm going to start with that the soil is kind of like a magnet

[2520.6s - 2548.2s]: okay so it's it's it's charged the soil particles have a negative charge like one end of the magnet right and the nutrient they're called nutrient ions but let's think of them as as nutrient elements they have different charges some of them have positive charges and some of them have negative charges so

[2548.2s - 2573.4s]: so if the soil is a magnet holding on to the the mainly the positive charge and then the positive charge can hold on to a negative charge you begin to see how how everything sticks together so to speak so cat ions are positively charged nutrient elements like potassium calcium

[2573.4s - 2603.2s]: magnesium and hydrogen the ones we really think about you know as farmers and gardeners are potassium calcium and magnesium and the cat ion exchange capacity is the ability of the soil to hold on to those positively charged nutrient elements so if if it can hold on to a lot

[2603.2s - 2625.8s]: it's full if it can't hold on to a lot it's a little meager so technically that cat ion exchange capacity if it's higher shows you that your soil is naturally a little more fertile in that it has the ability to hold calcium magnesium potassium

[2625.8s - 2654.4s]: and then if I may just add because it's all interconnected that that there's a cat ion balancing or cat ion ratio so the soil has this cat ion exchange capacity meaning that it can hold on to a lot and and it can exchange them like you're in a card game right you're in a card game and you're you're changing this card for that card

[2654.4s - 2683.9s]: that's what the soil does with the exchangeable cat ions but the the base saturation or the ratio of calcium magnesium and potassium can be just as important as the absolute amounts in fact my late husband said he didn't even care how much calcium or magnesium the soil had he wanted the well he did care

[2683.9s - 2712.5s]: but he he had more importantly he wanted to know the ratio of calcium to magnesium and the ratio of potassium to magnesium so that's why we want to know about cat ion exchange capacity it lets us know how good our soil is at holding on to and exchanging those positively charged nutrients and of course if they can exchange them fast they exchange them also with our plant roots

[2712.5s - 2730.8s]: and that's why we want to know amazing so one very simple way to understand this by analogy is it's the strength of the magnet I like that yes that's great okay I'm going to I'm going to use that

[2730.8s - 2760.7s]: okay okay and what what is what is driving or affecting changes in the strength of the magnet so to speak well basically it's it's it's it's many biochemical things and chemical things but it's also soil structure and what you know my grandfather used to call soil till so if you have good soil particles with good soil till

[2760.8s - 2790.1s]: they're going to have more magnet strength if you've got them all compacted and squished down and you don't have a lot of sites available in a nice big round particle that's not squished then then you don't have quite as much strength so the way we the way we add nutrients to our soil

[2790.1s - 2807.1s]: when we add things like cover crops can increase the soil organic matter and increasing the soil organic matter helps with the cat ion exchange capacity okay oh my gosh that helps me understand this so much more I love it

[2809.4s - 2828.6s]: so one of the things that jumped out at me is not only do you have strategies like cover cropping and full your sprays and composting and so on but you also have developed your own growing mix called Helen's growing mix can you tell us about that and when we might want to use that

[2828.6s - 2858.3s]: yes and remember that I call it as an as an intervention mix so if I have everything working with my adding residues regularly not all at once in the spring I used to add used to make a lot of compost and add it all at once in the spring and my soil micro community felt a little like we all fill after a huge Thanksgiving dinner you're a little sluggish so if you have little amounts

[2858.3s - 2878.1s]: of food all the time adding residues regularly through the soil throughout the season that microbial community is you know is a little happier that way I got off on a tangent there tell me remind me exactly what you wanted me to

[2878.1s - 2906.9s]: yeah yeah we're on the Helen's growing mix like you want the recipe and indeed it is there in the book so if I'm adding things regularly I get to what I think of as a dynamic equilibrium that the amount going in is being digested and mineralized made into available forms

[2906.9s - 2924.3s]: for the plant by the soil microbes and the amount that the plant roots need is balanced with the amount that's decomposing and releasing at any one time so there's my perfect dynamic equilibrium.

[2924.3s - 2948.6s]: Unfortunately there's climatic things cold and rainy and things that make that dynamic equilibrium not always work also mistakes that I make as a as a farmer can upset that dynamic equilibrium as well so when things aren't working as smoothly it's early in the spring

[2948.6s - 2978.6s]: the soil is still being cold I've had to do some tillage because maybe I've had a perennial weed problem so I've disrupted my microbial community a little bit and they don't like to work if it's below 45 degrees Fahrenheit there they're going to go on strike then I might have to add what I call my magic mix or my intervention mix and what I do is I make this up and I

[2978.6s - 3008.5s]: have a 30 gallon garbage can and I mix in things like a falfa meal and some of the micronutrients and and then I mix it all up and I try to mix it in a warmer area but I don't always get that and then I apply it as a root drench to my crops as I put them out so I give them a little bit of the

[3009.8s - 3038.5s]: boost right as they're going in and I also do it if for some reason things aren't moving smoothly we're not getting that natural nutrient cycling and recycling and my plants start to look a little nutrient deficient and then I jump right on it I don't let my plant struggle I give them some of the magic mix

[3038.5s - 3068.5s]: so that they can again start cycling nutrients from the the whole soil organic matter system fertility that I I talk about in the book and I do I do have a section because this is part of being curious and paying attention and listening to your plants I do have a section on the book including photos of new

[3068.5s - 3093.0s]: nutrient deficiencies so that you can jump right on it you can we tend to over fertilize as farmers and gardeners even organic farmers and gardeners so if we're going to cautiously move away from that we want to make sure we know the language that our plants are speaking to us we want to know the signs of nutrient deficiency so we can jump on it fast.

[3093.0s - 3123.0s]: So that's that's that's one of the get out of jail free cards in the book so that we can we can try to have this lovely ecological balance we can try to work with our microbes but if something doesn't go quite right we we need to have we have less actual inputs if that makes sense Aaron and more intellectual watching and monitoring going on.

[3123.0s - 3124.0s]: In our gardens.

[3125.8s - 3132.3s]: I love that it's like pay more attention do less work.

[3134.1s - 3142.8s]: Yes exactly that you know that is so that is better said than I said it in the book pay attention do less work.

[3142.8s - 3170.7s]: Wow well Ellen it is such a joy to have this opportunity to visit with you today on our podcast and I want to encourage our audience to get a copy of the ecological farm a minimalist no till no spray selective weeding grow your own fertilizer system for organic agriculture get it at Chelsea Green dot com

[3172.2s - 3200.6s]: and Helen want to encourage folks if they're interested to check out our simple gardening wisdom video course at why on earth dot org you can get the module that Helen created for us and it is such a joy to have this conversation with you Helen and to be able to learn a bit more from you and about what we can do in our gardens and farms.

[3200.6s - 3205.7s]: To collaborate more harmoniously with the natural world.

[3206.6s - 3218.9s]: Thank you for being both a nerd and wanting all those nerdy discussions and asking great questions and also understanding that it really is vital to collaborate.

[3221.0s - 3225.8s]: Truly here here well thank you so much Helen what a joy.

[3225.8s - 3228.4s]: Thank you bye bye.

[3230.7s - 3240.7s]: The why on earth community stewardship and sustainability podcast series is hosted by Aaron William Perry author thought leader and executive consultant.

[3241.4s - 3254.2s]: The podcast and video recordings are made possible by the generous support of people like you to sign up as a daily weekly or monthly supporter please visit why on earth dot org backslash support.

[3254.2s - 3258.0s]: Support packages start at just one dollar per month.

[3258.8s - 3264.0s]: The podcast series is also sponsored by several corporate and organization sponsors.

[3264.7s - 3271.8s]: You can get discounts on their products and services using the code why on earth all one word with a why.

[3272.9s - 3277.8s]: These sponsors are listed on the why on earth dot org backslash support page.

[3278.3s - 3288.2s]: If you found this particular podcast episode especially insightful informative or inspiring please pass it on and share it with a friend who you think will also enjoy it.

[3289.1s - 3296.3s]: Thank you for tuning in. Thank you for your support and thank you for being a part of the why on earth community.

related_episodes.title: Ep 153 – Joy & Eric McEwen, Authors, Raising Resilient Bees (CGP and SGWVC instructors)
Ep 151 – Nicolette Hahn Niman, Author, “Defending Beef” – Regenerative Grazing (CGP)
Ep 146 – Matthew Derr, Executive Director, Chelsea Green Foundation
Ep 142 – Maria Rodale, Author,Love, Nature, Magic(CGP)
Ep 136 – Ben Raskin, Author,The Woodchip Handbook(CGP)
Ep 124 – Nick DiDomenico, Co-Founder, Drylands Agroecology Research (featured SGWVC instructor)

segments.text: Welcome to the Y on Earth Community Podcast. I'm your host, Aaron William Perry. And today we're visiting with the author of the ecological farm, Helen Atto, Hi Helen. How are you today?
I'm great. Thank you. I'm so happy. We have the opportunity to talk with you about your incredible book. It's beautiful and such a robust resource.
Thank you. It's an honor to be here. I appreciate your kind words.

Helen Atto has worked for 35 years to connect farming food systems, land stewardship and conservation. She bought a new farm in Montana in 2023, but still consults for and monitors ongoing research at Woodley Farm in Eastern Oregon.

She serves as a consultant with farmers across the United States and internationally. Helen and her late husband, Carl Rosado, co-owned and operated a certified organic orchard in California, where they pioneered methods for raising apples, peaches and other tree fruits without the use of any type of pesticides.

Her on farm research includes ecological weed and insect management, organic minimal soil disturbance systems for vegetable and orchard crops and managing living mulches for soil and habitat building.

She is a contributing writer to the organic gardeners' handbook of natural pest and disease controlling other books. She has served as a board member for the Organic Farming Research Foundation and Advisor for the Wild Farm Alliance.

She has a master's degree in horticulture from Rutgers University and has worked in education and research at the University of Arkansas, Rutgers University and Oregon State University and served as a horticulture extension agent in Montana, where she annually taught and organic master gardener course.
Now, Helen, this book, of course, is published by our good friends at Chelsea Green Publishing and I'm holding this up for the camera here for our video audience.

It is such an incredible resource, truly an amazing comprehensive and detailed resource and it is also absolutely beautiful. It has so many wonderful photos and a variety of other charting graphics to help us understand some of these complex issues and yeah, congrats this book is so beautiful.

Thank you. Chelsea Green, very patient with me with all the photographs that I've taken from all three farms that I have owned and operated in Montana and California and Oregon and now back to Montana again.
Full circle, right?
Full circle indeed.

Well, I'd like to kind of dive right in because basically the book you've got it organized in two major sections and at the beginning of the first section, you describe the principles for managing ecological relationships, which really helps to frame up, I think, best practices and in the right sort of philosophical practical.
So, I think that's a very practical approach to taking good care of our gardens and our farms, our soil and our plants.
I was hoping to kick us off. You could walk us through the principles, which I've gotten written out here if you want me to enumerate them and you probably have the memorized.

I do, I don't have the memorized in order anymore, I kind of have the memorized in the ones that that I find to be the most vital and I do need to tell you that my late husband, Carl and I worked on all of those principles and again came up with them as we did experiments and and managed our farms in California and Montana and then in Oregon.

But we did borrow the first three are borrowed from the USDA soil health initiative, which is kind of interesting because it shows that so many of us are thinking about what is vital for soil and farm and garden health, I think now.

So, I think what I might do is touch on the most important of them and how they interact because what Carl and I realized as we continued farming that we started out, you know, all about yield and trying to get good organic yields and trying to figure out what to do to grow our particular crops as well as we could organically.

And over time we evolved to this realization that it was less about focusing on individual crops and more about all of the ecological function within the farm environment and and all of the interacting and overlapping ecological principles.

So, when I talk about these 10 principles, they all interact. So, the first three or four focus on soil and most vitally as I'm sure your audience is well aware of where we're preaching to the choir here when we say that above ground and below ground diversity is the key to managing ecological principles.

And we want to have as much plant diversity both above ground and below ground as possible to encourage a healthy and strong microbial community in that magic area, the rises fear, which is where the soil and the microbes and the plant roots are commingled together.

And if there's one magic place in our garden, it's the rises fear. So, diversity, then the next one is once we have this lovely diversity or as we're building up plant diversity and microbial diversity, we want to disturb it as little as possible.
And one of the ways to think about that is how can we disturb the soil as little as possible so that we can maintain a living root year round.
That doesn't necessarily mean a growing root in Montana, when the ground is freezing, we don't necessarily have growing roots but we have living roots.
And then we move on to get a little more specific and say try and focus on a carbon-based system rather than a high nitrogen-based system.
We used to as farmers and gardeners say, well, let's just figure out how to get as much nitrogen and phosphorus and potassium, all the nutrients but particularly nitrogen to the crops as possible.

But over time, we learned and now the soil, microbial and biochemical research is starting to agree and concur or we're concurring with them that a higher carbon-based system, meaning that there's more carbon than nitrogen.
So the ratio of carbon to nitrogen in the things that we add to our soils, the fertilizers, the soil amendments, the carbon part is higher than the nitrogen part.
And then as we focus on a carbon-based rather than a super-over-nitrogen fertilizer system or soil fertility system, we want to think about where that carbon comes from.
And can we grow our own carbon or collect our carbon as close to our gardens and farms as possible rather than importing it from somewhere else?

And then we move on to how the things below ground and the soil health of the system interacts with things like, well, some people call them weeds, we'll call them other vegetation, non-crop vegetation, and insects in the system and other microorganisms, the good guys and the ones we aren't as happy with.

The ones that cause disease. So what we try to do with building the soil system is have it also multi-tack as building a habitat system, a habitat for beneficial soil microorganisms and beneficial insects,
soil our predators and parasites that prey upon pest insects, and then also beneficial microorganisms and insects that prey upon disease pathogens and even weed seeds.

So we're trying to create habitat as we create soil. So we're choosing a soil fertility system that also maintains a living root in the soil and maintains season-long sequential bloom for especially predators and parasites that require pollen and nectar as their food.
And then we're trying to fertilize only selectively, weed only selectively, and maintain undisturbed habitat in a good portion of the farm or the garden at any one time.

And that kind of brings all of the 10 principles together into the overlapping ecological system, but you can just read through the principles one at a time, always remembering that you really can't take one without the other or others.
Oh, wonderful. So I think you're too nerdy on that.

That's perfect. I love it. And yeah, if you if you're okay with it, I think I'll go ahead and read the 10 in order as you lay them out in the book because I think it really helps a lot of us kind of get oriented in this kind of complex system.

So yeah, number one is you're going to laugh and I'm in a laugh and say that my husband and I never believed in recipes, but we came up with these 10 principles because people always wanted recipes. So absolutely, I've given given the nerdy big picture of how all the principles interact. Now you give it to us as a recipe.

Yeah, here's the recipe and on that note, I've been able to myself learn some techniques for cooking from some remarkable chefs over the years. And so I rarely use recipes. And of course, for many of us who want to do more gardening and have more success gardening and farming, the recipes can be helpful.
And to that end, I'm thrilled to share and announce that in partnership with Chelsea Green Publishing and others, the wider community is rolling out our simple gardening wisdom video course.

And of course, there's a module that you've provided, Helen, that is so informative and helpful just helping us all get a bit more comfortable so that perhaps one day many more of us won't need the recipes any longer.
Absolutely, and I still use them too, but I'm I'm I'm teasing.

Yeah, so here's here's how you lay it laid out in the book. It's it's number one. Create above and below ground diversity. Number two, minimize soil disturbances. Number three, maintain growing roots. You're round. Number four, grow your own carbon. Number five, add organic residues. All season.

Number six, focus on carbon fertilizers. Number seven, recycle rather than important nutrients. Number eight, fertilize selectively. Number nine, weed selectively. And number 10, create habitat in the field essentially kind of reintering what you've already just articulated.

But I gotta say like one of the things I really appreciate about your book is that it is absolutely chalk full of very specific methods and strategies to manage all kinds of situations and scenarios that will encounter in our gardens and in our farms and orchards.

And the way you've organized the book is makes it so useful and not nearly I think as intimidating as it as it might otherwise be. And I noted a few specifics that I wanted to share their audience and discuss with you, but before getting to that.

I wanted to ask just out of curiosity being an author myself, you mentioned that Chelsea Green was patient with you. How long did it take you to put this book together because it clearly has many years worth of experience and wisdom in it.

Actually, it's really about 40 years. So I started doing on farm research in the 1990s on my farm in Montana and in the early 2000s and I got research grants and so I would of course write it all down and do even more monitoring.

So I had all of that detail and then my brewing in husband was doing his own on farm research in California and ironically we were developing similar methods using living mulchus for example to to maintain our living root in the soil year round as well as our crops and to create habitat for the soil.

So that is close to our crops as possible. So we used living mulches and and then when we met we had the courage to push ourselves even further on his farm in California where he was of course, remember doing perennial crops orchard crops and in Montana, I was mainly doing annual crops mainly vegetables.
So we did on farm research together and of course we kept all of our notes and that went into the book and then we moved to Oregon and started a farm together and we went crazy.

We really pushed the ecological envelope as far as we could go and we set up some long term experiments to see what could we really get away with in terms of those 10 ecological principles, how far could we really go to not disturbing the soil, how much no till could we do with the orchard it was easy and we kept good records of that.

A little more challenging with the annual vegetable crops and we kept records of that. So between Carl's farm and my farm in Montana and then getting together and farming together in California and then in Oregon, it was 40 years.

It took about a year to write the book and do literature searches because I wanted to see what what the science was saying about some of these things Carl and I were excited about and then Chelsea Green, my wonderful editor at Chelsea Green helped me and was very firm with making it less ecologically complex.

So we maintained the ecological complexity but we wrote about it in a way that wasn't quite so complex. So thank you for that. The first section is is is pretty unusual and then the second section we get into well, okay, we want to talk about managing ecological principles and and we want to talk about how to do.

How to practically do all of those things that are in the 10 ecological principles but okay, so if you're starting with a low soil fertility system or if you're starting with a garden or a farm that has particular pest or disease problems, then what do you do?

And the second half of the book is basically all of that but still making sure that we remember that there are ecological impacts to everything we do. So so I present the least ecological impact up to the heavier ecological impact in the second part.
And that's why it took long to write the book.

Yeah, it will it's it's really such a tremendous resource and I'm excited to dive into a few of the details with you and yet we'll nerd out a little bit but I thought with your permission, I would quote you reading the final paragraph of your introduction because it sets such a sweet and I might even say,
a spiritual tone to the experience you're sharing with us working with these ecosystems, these organisms, the soil and so forth. And may I read this quoting you?
Absolutely.

Okay, you write when you are feeling troubled, fearful or uncertain, there is a certainty intending plants and growing your own food, nurturing the healthy goodness in a field of multi colored kale and lettuces or coapsing so much sweetness from a special peach tree.
It all makes me feel I belong safely wherever I am.
The process of creating farms and gardens opens my eyes to awe, tunes my ears to listening and offers the gifts of curiosity, discovery and deep connection.

Being part of this farming revolution, I reap my own personal revolution for free, healthy farming in which nature is invited to participate, grows healthy food that in turn grows healthy humans resistant to disease and stress.
These reconnected healthy farms and gardens are in turn resilient and resistant to plant disease and stress.
And it's just such a, when I've read that, I was stunned. I loved the way in which you speak to the deep solace in sanctuary, so many of us experience when we're gardening and farming.
And kind of leave us with that in the introduction as we start our journey into a whole lot of very, very practical and technical information.
Isn't it lovely the synergy between human health, farm health, soil health, environmental health and that when we stop and pay attention, I think we can, we can feel and see that synergy.
No doubt about it and perhaps among the many great tasks before us, before humanity, this particular work is core and central.
Yes, good food growing makes good humans. I think you hit the nail on the head.

I absolutely love it. Well, let's let's nerd out just a little bit. I was struck. I mean, throughout this book, not only are there many beautiful photographs, there are also many very compelling charts, flow charts, data charts to help us pretty quickly understand the information that you're conveying and the strategies and methods that you're sharing.
One that jumped out at me is on page 33, the soil revolution section and it's the complex, relatively complex interconnectedness.
We see going on with the roots, the rhizosphere with nutrients, microbial activity, organic carbon, luteolin, rhizobia, bacteria, biochannin, I don't even know if I'm saying that right.
Are muscular micro-rise, can you walk us through what's going on in this picture?
And you know, you're going to laugh at me, but actually, I simplified that.
So there are still that's the rhizosphere that I was talking about in a very beginning. That's the magic if we have a magic area in in farming and gardening.
It's right there in the rhizosphere because what's happening is the plant above ground is taking in carbon. It's taking it in sunlight.
And then it's manufacturing compounds, biochemicals, proteins. And the carbon that it harvest from the sun ends up throughout the plant and a good portion in the roots.
And then it leaks some of that carbon out or you could say it shares some of that carbon with the microbial community that is associating with the roots.

And then a myriad of things are going on. There are different, not only just carbon is being leaked out of the root, but some of those biochemicals that the plant makes are being leaked out or shared with the microbial community.
And they act as signals and they signal different microorganisms to associate with the roots.
And for example, one that probably everybody's heard about is mycorrhizae. And mycorrhizae, associate and become interconnected with the root because of a biochemical that that plant exudes.

And the mycorrhizae, I know you and that starts the association. And then the association, that interaction with this particular fungi, the mycorrhizae, then allows other things to go back to the plant.
And in this case with mycorrhizae, it's recycled phosphorus and nitrogen. And what mycorrhizae do, they're associated with the plant root.
But they basically extend that plant's root out into the soil farther than the plant root could go on its own because that wonderful mycorrhizae has mycelium that just grows out into the soil.
That's just one example. There are so many other microorganisms.
You mentioned rhizobium, of course, are the bacteria that associate with a legume root and allow it to fix nitrogen from the atmosphere.
And so then it doesn't need as much from the soil. But there's a whole bunch of other things going on. There are antibiotic microorganisms that are helping create a disease-free environment.
There are microorganisms that help plants take up and utilize iron and a micronutrient. And of course, it's not all just good guys.
There are microorganisms that can actually attack the plant and they too need a signal.

So they need a biochemical coming from the plant and researchers are finding that plants, we're going to get back, of course, full circle to those plants that have a healthy amount of nutrients, but not an excess amount of nutrients like an excess amount of nitrogen, for example.
Plants that are not healthy, exude different signals and then those disease-causing microorganisms say, oh, oh, I see that. That's my signal to move in.
So what's happening is that half of what's going on is that the plant is communicating with the whole soil community with the biochemicals that it exudes.
And then the other half is it's producing nutrients, what we call liquid carbon or some soil scientists called liquid carbon, that the microorganisms need for their growth and their health.

And so there's a sharing going on on that side and then the microorganisms that are using that carbon might change things right at that root surface that makes it easier for other nutrients to be taken up by the root.
So there's sharing and communicating and a complexity of biochemical interactions that allow nutrient cycling to be very efficient.

I love it. I'm just smiling here to here right now. And you know, one of the things that has really impacted the work that we're doing at the White Earth community is not only literally working with the soil ecology, but also learning from it, metaphorically speaking, and thinking about a neural network.
And analogy for the kind of work that we're doing through our ambassador network and in communities and with thought leaders and authors all around the world.
And this this sense of connectivity, the sense of information sharing, this sense of resource sharing is so inspiring. And it's fundamental obviously to terrestrial life on this planet.
And I forget where the quote comes from something like, you know, we all we humans owe our existence to a few inches of living soil and the fact that it rains or whatever.

And I'm really curious, can you help our audience get the impression of how awesome these networks are, especially the high fee, mycelial networks, like how far they can reach and how many different plants and trees and various organisms can connect in with the network like that.

You know, that's exactly that's so important what you said it shifts our paradigm doesn't it when we think in terms of these interconnections rather than discrete plants with discrete things happening like taking up fertilizer that we supply.

It's a whole different perspective, I think so so yes, good for you. So my carize I do need to tell you the wonderful thing about my carize as that in native plant consist systems for a system, for example, they can be they are the norm rather than the anomaly and not just my carize but other fungi there's free living fungi.

So by meaning that they're not associated with the roots there in just in the soil, there's free living bacteria as well as the plants associated fungi and bacteria, my carize are are make up the greatest biomass in the soil, but in native plant communities, they are the canary in the coal mine when it comes to disturbance and tillage.

So if you till the soil too much if you disturb it with cultivation for managing weeds and if you over fertilize with higher nitrogen, higher phosphorus as opposed to higher arbon, which is what the microbial community really needs a lot of.

You will create an environment where there may be no my carize which is very discouraging hence why we want to have those those living roots in the soil because remember my carize have to associate with the plant and then they're not free living and then they'll extend those those wonderful mycelian plants.
So I'm going to put them in a very very far throughout a system where there are roots there for them to to go from one root to another root to another root.

But if we disturb the soil, we won't have certainly the mycorrhizae the fungi in fact are the first ones to go when we garden or farm in a way that we add a lot of excessive fertilizer and that can even be too too much good fertilizer too much high nitrogen compost.
We can there are other bacteria and other fungi that will dominate and the diversity of microorganisms will be diminished if that makes sense.

Yes, quite yes and my understanding is that in native healthy ecosystems, we can see a micro isle high full networks extending across hundreds of square miles right presumably it's it's extraordinary if you have roots interconnecting or not even the roots interconnecting although that will happen in a good path.

So in a poly culture or many species, the roots will actually share space but but in a forest where you have miles and miles of of of interactions, you have a whole diversity of micro organisms sharing root space and utilizing different resources so that they're not out competing each other for any one particular resource.
Amazing yeah, may we may we humans learn from this wisdom and sophistication yeah yes.
